Based off of gravitational effects, and/or based off of the surface colour 
of the star, we can determine it's surface temperature, and with that it's 
mass, and with that it's volume, and with that it's total energy output. We 
then compare the total energy output to it's observed energy output, and 
voila!

in a cluster can help us easily assume the distances of the other stars.

temperature and luminosity, which is extremely helpful in determining 
distances!

Well, assuming you're travelling at relativistic speed things get a little 
complicated, in relation to someone on earth you would take 25,000 humans 
lifetimes(a little more actually cause nothing can reach the speed of light)
But to you(inside the ship) time would slow down substantially:
you can calculate how much it slow down by Lorentz transformation(if you 
didn't change speed)
# If you're travelling at 99.99% of light speed:

time(earth) = 2 500 000*1.01 = 2 525 000 years = 25 250 lifes
distance    = velocity*time 
so: distance(2 500 000 light year) = c*time(earth) = c*25 250


in one life time light cross 9.454255e+17 meters
now things get harder:

time(ship) = ( 25 250   -    c*25 250/c²   )/squareroot( 1 - 0.9999²)
time(ship) = (25 250    -      25 250/c     )/squareroot(0.00019999)
time(ship) = (       1     -       1/c    )25 250 * 0.01414178206
time(ship) = (1 - [1/9.454255e+17]   )* 357.079997015 ~ 357 lives

To someone inside the ship It would take around 357 lives to complete this 
travel while someone on earth would need 25 250 lives to watch the ship 
land. Be carefull, this has nothing to do with the time light takes to 
travel from Andromeda to Earth, I'm not taking it into account. You could 
think of this times like this: if were a clock on Earth and another inside 
the ship, both on zero when it take off. At the time the ship landed the 
one inside would be showing 357 and the one on Earth would be showing 25 
520.

Here is the equation for relativistic speeds when there's no aceletion:

time(ship) = LorentzFactor*{time(earth) - 
distance*speed(ship)/(lightspeed²) }
Lorentzfactor = 1 /squareroot{ 1 - [speed(ship)/lightspeed]²  }

comments.text:
+Tyr Caelestis Consus  "how old something is" isn't a measure of how 
correct it is. If that was the case, one could argue that Hinduism is the 
'one true religion', since it's history precedes that of all other 
religions to date. Or that practices like slavery or stoning are more 
correct as practices since they have been around for so long.

>"You are just blind sheep following the the unproven theory of science. "
In a sense, everything is 'unproven', you cannot (reasonably) be 100% 
certain of anything; you cannot be 100% certain that anything you 
experience even truly exists. We all have to make assumptions about 
reality, but what is important is an assumption's predictive capability, or 
to what degree that assumption is conducive to objective reality. Some 
assumptions (like dropping a ball in a gravitational field) have such 
rigorously consistent results, that we operate >as if< it was 100% true, 
but these actions say nothing about what >could ultimately< be true. Such 
are the issues with many religions: they draw absolutes, which, time and 
time again, are unreasonable in the face of what we objectively observe 
about reality. What you refer to as "the unproven theory of science" has 
vastly 'proven' itself to have more predictive capability and universal 
utility than the absurd claims of religion.

>"People shouldn't just blindly believe everything they are told. "
You're correct in saying this, which is ironic given the nature of how most 
people come to believe in religion (and given, how i suspect, you came to 
accept the teachings of your religion.) However, just because you can 
acknowledge that not everything you experience can be reasonably trusted, 
doesn't mean you adhere to such a principle in practice. If i'm not 
mistaken, it is very popular among Christian practices to submit oneself to 
God in an act of total faith. In fact, many christian apologists argue that 
"atheists don't have access to the same information that Christians do, as 
they have not accepted Jesus as their personal lord and savior. This is why 
they can never reconcile the Christian perspective, and we can." Well isn't 
that interesting. I would say that fits your description of 'blindly 
believing something they are told' more than anything.

The idea that "you must first accept >that it's true<, to see >how< it's 
true" is a dangerous prospect.

I don't mean to accuse you specifically of adhering to such a practice. For 
all I know you could have very well accepted your religion on objective 
merits which you have observed (in which case, I would entice you to 
revisit such assumptions; really challenge them on the basis of evidence.)

Lastly, accusing the scientific process of being untrustworthy is just 
relative ignorance in the face of all the combined benefits (which we reap 
daily) that scientific reasoning has allowed us to experience, and I am 
more than comfortable lending credit where credit is due to such a practice.

I think it's reasonable to say that rational people don't "praise" or 
"worship" anything, (if your definitions of worship and praise means: 
"assign more value than is deserved" or "assign value through faith alone" 
or "assign value despite strong evidence against"), they assign credit 
where credit is due, and to the degree which it is deserved and no-more 
than that.

captions.text: Light is the fastest thing we know.

It's so fast that we measure
enormous distances

by how long it takes
for light to travel them.

In one year, light travels
about 6,000,000,000,000 miles,
a distance we call one light year.

To give you an idea of just
how far this is,

the Moon, which took the Apollo astronauts
four days to reach,
is only one light-second from Earth.

Meanwhile, the nearest star beyond
our own Sun is Proxima Centauri,
4.24 light years away.

Our Milky Way is on the order of
100,000 light years across.
The nearest galaxy to our own, Andromeda,
is about 2.5 million light years away
Space is mind-blowingly vast.

But wait, how do we know how
far away stars and galaxies are?

After all, when we look at the sky,
we have a flat, two-dimensional view.

If you point you finger to one star,
you can't tell how far the star is,
so how do astrophysicists figure that out?
For objects that are very close by,

we can use a concept called
trigonometric parallax.
The idea is pretty simple.
Let's do an experiment.

Stick out your thumb and 
close your left eye.

Now, open your left eye and
close your right eye.
It will look like your thumb has moved,

while more distant background objects
have remained in place.

The same concept applies when
we look at the stars,

but distant stars are much, much 
farther away than the length of your arm,
and the Earth isn't very large,

so even if you had different telescopes
across the equator,
you'd not see much of a shift in position.

Instead, we look at the change in the
star's apparent location over six months,

the halfway point of the Earth's
yearlong orbit around the Sun.

When we measure the relative positions
of the stars in summer,

and then again in winter,
it's like looking with your other eye.

Nearby stars seem to have moved
against the background
of the more distant stars and galaxies.

But this method only works for objects no
more than a few thousand light years away.

Beyond our own galaxy,
the distances are so great

that the parallax is too small to detect
with even our most sensitive instruments.

So at this point we have to rely 
on a different method
using indicators we call standard candles.

Standard candles are objects whose
intrinsic brightness, or luminosity,
we know really well.

For example, if you know how bright
your light bulb is,

and you ask your friend to hold
the light bulb and walk away from you,

you know that the amount of light
you receive from your friend
will decrease by the distance squared.

So by comparing the amount 
of light you receive

to the intrinsic brightness 
of the light bulb,

you can then tell how far away
your friend is.

In astronomy, our light bulb turns out to
be a special type of star
called a cepheid variable.
These stars are internally unstable,

like a constantly inflating 
and deflating balloon.

And because the expansion and contraction
causes their brightness to vary,

we can calculate their luminosity
by measuring the period of this cycle,

with more luminous stars 
changing more slowly.

By comparing the light
we observe from these stars

to the intrinsic brightness we've
calculated this way,
we can tell how far away they are.

Unfortunately, this is still not 
the end of the story.

We can only observe individual stars
up to about 40,000,000 light years away,

after which they become 
too blurry to resolve.

But luckily we have another type
of standard candle:
the famous type 1a supernova.

Supernovae, giant stellar explosions
are one of the ways that stars die.
These explosions are so bright,

that they outshine the galaxies
where they occur.

So even when we can't see 
individual stars in a galaxy,

we can still see supernovae 
when they happen.

And type 1a supernovae turn out
to be usable as standard candles

because intrinsically bright ones
fade slower than fainter ones.

Through our understanding 
of this relationship
between brightness and decline rate,

we can use these supernovae 
to probe distances
up to several billions of light years away.

But why is it important to see
such distant objects anyway?
Well, remember how fast light travels.

For example, the light emitted by the Sun
will take eight minutes to reach us,

which means that the light we see now
is a picture of the Sun eight minutes ago.
When you look at the Big Dipper,

you're seeing what it looked like
80 years ago.
And those smudgy galaxies?
They're millions of light years away.

It has taken millions of years for
that light to reach us.

So the universe itself is in some sense
an inbuilt time machine.

The further we can look back,
the younger the universe we are probing.

Astrophysicists try to read the history
of the universe,

and understand how
and where we come from.

The universe is constantly sending us
information in the form of light.
All that remains if for us to decode it.

title: Light seconds, light years, light centuries: How to measure extreme distances - Yuan-Sen Ting
